Vaccine Information
(Birth) BCG

Bacille Calmette-Guerin is a vaccine for Tuberculosis (TB). The vaccination is given soon after birth, usually by 28 days after birth. Your baby will be given the BCG vaccination in the upper part of the left arm. The BCG vaccine is made from a weakened strain of TB bacteria. Because the bacteria in the vaccine is weak, it triggers the immune system to protect against the infection but does not give you TB. It provides consistent protection against the most severe forms of TB, such as TB meningitis in children
OPV 0

Oral poliovirus vaccines (OPV) are the predominant vaccine used in the fight to eradicate polio. OPV should be given at birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks and 14 weeks of age. The interval between all doses must be at least four weeks. The birth dose is known as OPV0; the subsequent doses are referred to as OPV1 (at 6 weeks), OPV2 (at 10 weeks), and OPV3 (at 14 weeks).You should not give OPV0 (the birth dose) to an infant who is more than 14 days old. If this dose has not been given by 14 days, miss this dose and wait until the child is six weeks old, and then give OPV1.
HEp-B 1

Hepatitis B vaccination, hepatitis B immunoglobulin, and the combination of hepatitis B vaccine plus hepatitis B immunoglobulin, all are considered as preventive for babies born to mothers infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV). Hepatitis B vaccine may be given as a stand-alone vaccine, or as part of a combination vaccine. The hepatitis B vaccine is given as a series of three shots. The first dose is given within 24 hours of birth. The second dose is given one to two months after the first dose, and the third dose is given between 6 months and 18 months of age
(6 weeks) DTwP 1

Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, and whole-cell pertussis vaccine can prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Diphtheria and pertussis spread from person to person. Tetanus enters the body through cuts or wounds. DIPHTHERIA (D) can lead to difficulty breathing, heart failure, paralysis, or death. Give one dose at each of these ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 through 18 months, and 4 through 6 years
IPV 1

IPV stands for Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine. It is a vaccine that is used to protect against polio, a viral disease that can cause paralysis and even death in severe cases.There are actually two types of IPV vaccines: IPV1 and IPV2. IPV1 refers specifically to the first dose of the inactivated polio vaccine that is given to infants as part of their routine immunization schedule. The IPV1 vaccine is usually given at 2 months of age, with subsequent doses given at 4 and 6 months, followed by a booster dose between 4 and 6 years of age
Hep B-2

The HEP B2 vaccine refers to the second dose of the hepatitis B vaccine series. The hepatitis B vaccine is a vaccine that is used to protect against hepatitis B, a viral infection that can cause liver damage, liver cancer, and even death in severe cases. The HEP B2 vaccine refers specifically to the second dose of the vaccine, which is given to provide additional protection against the hepatitis B virus. Like the first dose, the HEP B2 vaccine contains a small amount of a protein from the hepatitis B virus that triggers an immune response and helps the body build immunity against the virus.
Hib 1

: The HEP B2 vaccine refers specifically to the second dose of the vaccine, which is given to provide additional protection against the hepatitis B virus. Like the first dose, the HEP B2 vaccine contains a small amount of a protein from the hepatitis B virus that triggers an immune response and helps the body build immunity against the virus. The Hib vaccine is typically given as a series of two, three, or four doses, depending on the specific vaccine used and the age at which the vaccine is given. The Hib vaccine contains a protein from the Hib bacteria that triggers an immune response and helps the body build immunity against the bacteria. By building immunity, the vaccine helps prevent serious illnesses caused by the Hib bacteria.
Rotavirus

Rotavirus 1 vaccine refers to the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine series. The rotavirus vaccine is a vaccine that is used to protect against rotavirus, a highly contagious virus that can cause severe diarrhea, vomiting, and dehydration in infants and young children. The rotavirus vaccine is typically given as a series of two or three doses, depending on the specific vaccine used and the age at which the vaccine is given. The first dose, or Rotavirus 1 vaccine, is usually given at 2 months of age, with subsequent doses given at 4 and 6 months of age. The rotavirus vaccine contains weakened or inactivated forms of the rotavirus that trigger an immune response and help the body build immunity against the virus. By building immunity, the vaccine helps prevent rotavirus infections and the serious complications that can result from them.
PCV 1

PCV 1 vaccine refers to the first dose of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) series. The PCV vaccine is a vaccine that is used to protect against pneumococcal disease, which is caused by the Streptococcus pneumoniae bacteria and can cause serious infections such as pneumonia, meningitis, and bloodstream infections. The PCV vaccine contains pieces of the Streptococcus pneumoniae bacteria that trigger an immune response and help the body build immunity against the bacteria. By building immunity, the vaccine helps prevent pneumococcal infections and the serious complications that can result from them.
(10 weeks) DTwP 2

DTwP2 is a combination vaccine that protects against three infectious diseases: diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (whooping cough). It is an updated version of the DTwP2 vaccine, which has been used for many years. DTwP2 contains inactivated toxins from the bacteria that cause diphtheria and tetanus, as well as pieces of the bacteria that cause pertussis. When the vaccine is injected into the body, the immune system recognizes these components as foreign and produces antibodies to fight them. DTwP2 is generally considered safe and effective, although like all vaccines, it can cause side effects such as fever, soreness at the injection site, and fussiness. Serious side effects are rare.

IPV2 vaccine is an inactivated polio vaccine that provides protection against poliomyelitis, a highly infectious disease caused by the poliovirus. The IPV2 vaccine is a second-generation vaccine, developed after the original oral polio vaccine (OPV). IPV2 vaccine contains killed or inactivated poliovirus strains from all three types of the virus (type 1, type 2, and type 3). When the vaccine is injected into the body, it stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies against the virus, providing immunity. IPV2 vaccine is generally well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and fussiness. Serious side effects are rare.
Hib 3

Hib 3 vaccine is a vaccine that protects against Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria, which can cause severe infections in infants and young children, including pneumonia, meningitis, and blood infections. The Hib 3 vaccine is typically given as a series of three or four doses, with the first dose given at 2 months of age, the second dose given at 4 months of age, and the third dose given at 6 months of age. A fourth booster dose may be given at 12-15 months of age. Hib 3 vaccine is usually given as part of a combination vaccine that includes protection against other diseases such as diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, and polio. The vaccine is generally well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and fussiness. Serious side effects are rare.
Rotavirus 3

Rotavirus 3 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against rotavirus, which is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children. The vaccine is typically given orally and is available in two forms - the Rotarix and RotaTeq vaccines. The Rotarix vaccine is given in two doses, at 2 and 4 months of age. The RotaTeq vaccine is given in three doses, at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. Both vaccines contain live attenuated (weakened) rotavirus strains that stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the virus. Rotavirus 3 vaccine is highly effective at preventing severe rotavirus infections and has been shown to significantly reduce hospitalizations and deaths due to rotavirus-related diarrhea.
PCV 3

PCV 3 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against pneumococcal disease, which is caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae. The vaccine is usually given to infants and young children as part of a series of injections. The PCV 3 vaccine is designed to protect against the three most common strains of pneumococcal bacteria that cause serious infections, including pneumonia, meningitis, and blood infections. The vaccine contains pieces of the bacteria that stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the bacteria. If a child is later exposed to the actual bacteria, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection. PCV 3 vaccine is generally safe and effective, with a high degree of protection against pneumococcal disease. The vaccine is usually well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and fussiness. Serious side effects are rare.
(6 months) OPV 1

OPV 1 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against polio, a viral infection that can cause paralysis and even death. The vaccine is a live attenuated (weakened) oral vaccine that is given by mouth. OPV 1 vaccine is usually given to infants and young children in a series of doses. The first dose is typically given at 6 weeks of age, followed by two more doses at 10 and 14 weeks of age. A booster dose may be given between 16-18 months of age. OPV 1 vaccine is highly effective at preventing polio and has been instrumental in the near-eradication of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the poliovirus. If a child is later exposed to the actual poliovirus, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection. OPV 1 vaccine is generally safe and well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and fussiness. Serious side effects are rare.
Hep-B 3

Hep-B 3 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against hepatitis B, a viral infection that affects the liver and can lead to liver cancer, liver failure, and death. The vaccine is a recombinant vaccine that is given by injection. Hep-B 3 vaccine is typically given to infants and young children in a series of doses. The first dose is usually given shortly after birth, with additional doses given at 1-2 months and 6 months of age. The vaccine is also recommended for adolescents and adults who are at risk of contracting hepatitis B. Hep-B 3 vaccine is highly effective at preventing hepatitis B and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the hepatitis B virus. If a person is later exposed to the actual virus, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection.
(9 months) OPv 2

OPV2 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against polio, a viral infection that can cause paralysis and even death. The vaccine is a live attenuated (weakened) oral vaccine that is given by mouth. OPV2 vaccine is typically given to infants and young children in a series of doses. The first dose is usually given at 6 weeks of age, followed by two more doses at 10 and 14 weeks of age. A booster dose may be given between 16-18 months of age. OPV2 vaccine is highly effective at preventing polio and has been instrumental in the near-eradication of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the poliovirus. If a child is later exposed to the actual poliovirus, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection.

MMR 1 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against three viral diseases: measles, mumps, and rubella. The vaccine is a live attenuated (weakened) vaccine that is given by injection. MMR 1 vaccine is typically given to infants and young children in a series of doses. The first dose is usually given at 12-15 months of age, with a second dose given between 4-6 years of age. The vaccine is also recommended for adolescents and adults who have not been vaccinated against these diseases. MMR 1 vaccine is highly effective at preventing measles, mumps, and rubella, and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of these diseases globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the viruses. If a person is later exposed to any of the actual viruses, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection. MMR 1 vaccine is generally safe and well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and rash.
(9-12 months) Typhoid Conjugate Vaccine

Typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV) is a vaccine that provides protection against typhoid fever, a bacterial infection that is transmitted through contaminated food and water. The vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that is given by injection. TCV is typically given to individuals who are at high risk of contracting typhoid fever, such as travelers to areas where the disease is endemic, individuals who live in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene, and people who work in close proximity to those with typhoid fever. TCV is highly effective at preventing typhoid fever and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the Salmonella typhi bacterium, which causes typhoid fever. If a person is later exposed to the actual bacterium, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection. TCV is generally safe and well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and headache. Serious side effects are rare.
(12 months) Hep-A 1

Hepatitis A (Hep-A) vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against hepatitis A, a viral infection that affects the liver. The vaccine is an inactivated vaccine that is given by injection. Hep-A vaccine is typically given to individuals who are at high risk of contracting hepatitis A, such as travelers to areas where the disease is endemic, individuals who live in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene, men who have sex with men, and people with chronic liver disease. Hep-A vaccine is highly effective at preventing hepatitis A and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the hepatitis A virus. If a person is later exposed to the actual virus, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection.
(15 months) MMR 2

MMR 2 vaccine is a vaccine that provides a second dose of protection against three viral diseases: measles, mumps, and rubella. The vaccine is a live attenuated (weakened) vaccine that is given by injection. MMR 2 vaccine is typically given to children as a second dose, usually between the ages of 4-6 years. It is also recommended for adolescents and adults who have not been vaccinated against these diseases and have not previously had measles, mumps, or rubella. MMR 2 vaccine is highly effective at preventing measles, mumps, and rubella, and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of these diseases globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the viruses. If a person is later exposed to any of the actual viruses, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection. MMR 2 vaccine is generally safe and well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and rash. Serious side effects are rare.
Varicella 1

Varicella 1 vaccine, also known as the chickenpox vaccine, is a vaccine that provides protection against varicella-zoster virus, the virus that causes chickenpox. The vaccine is a live attenuated (weakened) vaccine that is given by injection. Varicella 1 vaccine is typically given to children as a two-dose series, with the first dose given at 12 to 15 months of age, and the second dose given at 4 to 6 years of age. It is also recommended for adults who have not been vaccinated against chickenpox and have not previously had the disease. Varicella 1 vaccine is highly effective at preventing chickenpox, and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the varicella-zoster virus. If a person is later exposed to the actual virus, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection.
PCV booster

A PCV booster vaccine is typically given to children at 12 to 15 months of age, after they have completed their initial series of PCV vaccinations. The booster vaccine provides additional protection against pneumococcal disease by helping to maintain the immunity that was established with the initial vaccine doses. PCV booster vaccine is highly effective at preventing pneumococcal disease, and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of the disease globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the bacteria that cause pneumococcal disease. If a person is later exposed to the actual bacteria, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection.
(16-18 months) DTwP B1

DTwP B1 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against three bacterial infections: diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (whooping cough). The vaccine contains inactivated (killed) forms of the bacteria that cause these diseases. DTwP B1 vaccine is typically given to infants and young children as a series of doses, usually starting at 6 weeks of age and continuing through early childhood. The vaccine is usually given as part of a combination vaccine that includes protection against other diseases such as Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and hepatitis B. DTwP B1 vaccine is generally safe and well-tolerated, with mild side effects such as soreness at the injection site, fever, and fussiness. Serious side effects are rare.
B1 IPV B1

B1-IPV-B1 vaccine is a combination vaccine that provides protection against three viral infections: polio, hepatitis B, and diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTwP). The vaccine contains inactivated (killed) forms of the viruses and bacteria that cause these diseases.B1-IPV-B1 vaccine is typically given to infants and young children as a series of doses, usually starting at 6 weeks of age and continuing through early childhood. The vaccine is usually given as part of a combination vaccine that includes protection against other diseases such as Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib).B1-IPV-B1 vaccine is highly effective at preventing polio, hepatitis B, diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis, and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of these diseases globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the viruses and bacteria that cause these diseases.
Hib B1

Hib B1 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria, which can cause serious diseases such as meningitis, pneumonia, and sepsis in infants and young children. Hib B1 vaccine is usually given to infants and young children as a series of doses, starting at 6 weeks of age and continuing through early childhood. The vaccine may be given as a separate shot or as part of a combination vaccine that also provides protection against other diseases such as diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, and hepatitis B. Hib B1 vaccine is highly effective at preventing Hib infections and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of these diseases globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the Hib bacteria. If a person is later exposed to the actual bacteria, their immune system will be prepared to fight off the infection.
Hep-A 2

Hepatitis A (Hep-A) 2 vaccine is a vaccine that provides protection against the hepatitis A virus, which can cause liver inflammation and disease. The vaccine contains inactivated (killed) forms of the hepatitis A virus. Hep-A 2 vaccine is typically given as a series of two doses, with the second dose given 6-18 months after the first dose. The vaccine is usually given to children and adults who are at risk of contracting hepatitis A, such as those traveling to areas with high rates of the disease, people who work in healthcare or food preparation, and those with chronic liver disease. Hep-A 2 vaccine is highly effective at preventing hepatitis A infections and has been instrumental in reducing the incidence of these diseases globally. The vaccine works by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies against the hepatitis A virus.

OPV 3

The OPV 3 vaccine refers to the Oral Polio Vaccine, specifically the third dose in the series. The OPV vaccine is usually administered in a series of doses to ensure optimal protection. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a schedule of three doses of OPV for primary immunization, typically given at 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks of age. Additional doses, known as booster doses, may be recommended at a later age to further enhance immunity. Polio, also known as poliomyelitis, is a highly infectious viral disease caused by the poliovirus. It primarily affects young children and can lead to paralysis or even death. The OPV vaccine helps to prevent polio by providing immunity against the virus.
Varicella 2

The Varicella 2 vaccine, also known as the second dose of the Varicella vaccine, is used to protect against varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection, commonly known as chickenpox. The Varicella 2 vaccine contains live, attenuated (weakened) strains of the varicella-zoster virus. These strains are specifically chosen to stimulate an immune response in the body without causing the disease itself. Varicella, or chickenpox, is a highly contagious viral infection characterized by a rash of itchy, fluid-filled blisters. It is typically a mild illness in children, but it can cause more severe complications in adolescents, adults, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems. The Varicella vaccine helps prevent chickenpox and its associated complications.
MMR 3

The MMR 3 vaccine refers to the third dose of the MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) vaccine. The MMR 3 vaccine is a combination vaccine that contains live, attenuated (weakened) forms of the measles, mumps, and rubella viruses. These strains are specifically selected to stimulate an immune response without causing the diseases themselves. The MMR vaccine is usually administered as a series of two doses, and in some cases, a third dose may be recommended for certain individuals. The first dose is typically given between 12 and 15 months of age, and the second dose is administered between 4 and 6 years of age. The MMR 3 vaccine refers to the third dose, which may be given in situations where additional immunity is desired or required, such as during outbreaks or for certain high-risk individuals.
